text: hey everyone thomas joseph here now
today i'm really excited to talk to you
about something and that is the
difference between stock and broth bone
broth it's all the rage these days but
i'm going to demystify it for you tell
you a little bit about it and hopefully
i'll convince you to give up this canned
stuff that you keep in your pantry and
actually make some really flavorful
chicken stock to have on hand whenever
you need it
today i'm going to share with you how to
make a brown chicken stock my favorite
chicken stock and to start what do you
need well to make stock you need chicken
bones you can do this in a few different
ways you can ask your butcher to give
you the chicken parts that you know
nobody else is taking this is the
backbone of the chicken so this is
really great for a stock you can get a
bunch of chicken wings like this they
have a lot of bones in them so they're
really great for stock as well this is a
chicken neck good for stock and if
you're having trouble finding these
bones you can also use chicken legs
which is what i have here so the main
difference between a stock and a broth
is a stock is made with chicken or meat
bones and a broth is made using the meat
so that's the main difference there so
what i'm gonna do is drizzle a little
bit of oil over the top of these chicken
bones these chicken pieces and i'm going
to put this into a 400 degree oven i'm
going to roast all of this for about 40
minutes now that's how you get a dark
brown chicken stock if you wanted a
lighter chicken stock which i don't
really prefer that but you could
certainly make that you would skip this
whole roasting process the development
of color and flavor so you'd have
something that is a little bit more mild
so this is going into the oven 400
degrees again for about 45 minutes
all right
so our chicken parts the bones here have
been roasting for 40 minutes you can see
they're starting to develop color and
now a very classic thing to do here if
you're making a beef stock or if you're
making a chicken stock like i am today
is using a little bit of tomato paste
and this really helps in creating a
depth of flavor giving you a really rich
flavorful stock you only really need a
tablespoon of tomato paste you can kind
of spread it on top and then take a
pastry brush and you're just going to
brush the pieces coating them evenly now
this process of making a brown chicken
stock it's a little bit more labor
intensive there are a few more steps but
i really think that if you give yourself
the time and you try this you'll be
really happy with the result this is all
brushed nicely i'm going to add some

break apart two stalks of celery
some carrot as well so your traditional
mirepoix and some onion peeled and cut
into quarters
just scatter this in the pan here
and now this goes back into the oven
again 400 degrees for about 40 minutes
until the vegetables and the chicken
pieces are really dark and brown you
want that color because color is flavor
alright guys so into the oven
all right guys so this has been in the
oven for about 40 minutes you can see
how nice and dark the color is here
that's what you're looking for now you
want to put your roasting pan over a
burner set over a medium low heat you're
going to now take the bones
from your pan here
and transfer them to a large stock pot
so we'll pull this out even the
vegetables they can go in too because
this is going to add more flavor now
once you have all of the bones and the
vegetables in your pot here take about a
cup of water now you can use water here
or you could also use a red wine it's
really great it adds this extra
dimension of flavor and you're going to
deglaze your roasting pan to get all of
those wonderful colorful bits off the
bottom of the pan and this on the bottom
of the pan is called font and fond is
all of those caramelized meat juices and
vegetable juices they have tons and tons
of flavors so do not discard this guys
this is really a lot of great
concentrated flavor so just take
a wooden spoon and scrape up the bits as
this comes up to temperature it'll be
easier to do this and it also makes for

go right into your pot all of the little
bits have been scraped up from the
bottom of the pan this is
nice and hot now you want to turn off
your burner here and you're going to
pour all of this wonderful flavorful
liquid right into your pot
and so now this goes back onto the
burner you're going to add about three
quarts of water here
cover the bones but you don't need to
cover them that much
and now
i'm going to add for a little bit of
extra flavor i'm going to add some
peppercorns here and also one bay leaf
you want to bring this up to a boil now
reduce it to a simmer and you're going
to cook this anywhere between one and a
half to two and a half hours until a lot
of the water has evaporated the flavors
have melded and concentrated and every
so often you're going to want to skim
off any impurities that come to the
surface here so
two and a half hours and you are going
to have a really flavorful stock so the
stock has been simmering for about two
hours here and every so often you want
to go through and skim off any
impurities any little bits of foaminess
that come up to the top any excess fat
you want to skim off of your stock as
well
and when you're making stock you want to
monitor the heat you don't want it to
boil because what's going to happen if
you boil the stock all those impurities
that are coming up to the top they're
going to redistribute down to the bottom
and mix in and give you a cloudy stock
and now you want to remove all of the
big pieces from your pot here so all of
those bones all of the vegetables take a
big slotted spoon like this and remove
the majority of the bones here
and then you want to strain this mixture
through a fine mesh sieve to get out any
other
little particles
now i was talking about bone broth
before and bone broth is a bit of a
misnomer because
it's considered a broth but it's made
with bones which is actually the
opposite of the point of differentiation
between stock and broth remember guys a
stock is made with primarily bones and a
broth is made with meat so once you have
the majority of the big pieces of bones
and vegetables out you're going to
strain this through a fine mesh sieve
sometimes people will even strain this
through cheesecloth so there are no
